keyTakeAways: Radule Bojovic, a police officer in Hanover Park, Illinois, was arrested by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and accused of being an unlawful immigrant from Montenegro.
Bojovic overstayed his tourist visa, which expired in 2015, and had been living in the U.S. illegally for 10 years.
The arrest occurred during a targeted enforcement operation in Illinois, indicating ICE's ongoing focus on immigration compliance within public sector roles.
The Hanover Park Police Department claimed that Bojovic passed a rigorous background check and was legally authorized to work in the U.S. prior to employment.

DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin criticized the hiring of an illegal alien, calling it a violation of federal law and emphasizing that possessing a firearm without legal authorization is a felony.
Mayor Rodney Craig stated that village officials will monitor Bojovic’s immigration status and, if he is found eligible to remain and work, he will be reinstated to full police duties.
The incident has sparked public debate over hiring practices in law enforcement, especially regarding immigrant status and due diligence.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) arrested Radule Bojovic, a police officer in Hanover Park, Illinois, accusing him of being an unlawful immigrant from Montenegro who overstayed his tourist visa, which expired in 2015. The arrest occurred during a targeted enforcement operation, and Bojovic is alleged to have lived in the U.S. illegally for over a decade. Despite local officials asserting that due diligence was conducted—including FBI and Illinois State Police background checks—DHS officials criticized the hiring of an individual who violated federal immigration laws, emphasizing that illegal aliens cannot legally possess firearms. The Hanover Park Police Department and Mayor Rodney Craig have stated that the hiring process was thorough and that Bojovic will be reinstated if he is found legally authorized to remain in the U.S. The case has ignited public debate over hiring practices in law enforcement, especially concerning immigration status, and is part of a broader pattern of federal enforcement targeting public sector employees with immigration violations, as seen in a similar case involving an Iowa school superintendent.
